document_info.title: Detailed Herb Analysis for Oilahuasca
document_info.compiled_from: Claude.ai discussions with Rev. Ryan Van Kush

research_on_extract.quote: Apiole (1-allyl-2,5-dimethoxy-3,4-methylenedioxybenzene) and parsley leaves ethanolic extract containing it inhibit the rat liver microsomal... activities
research_on_extract.finding: Even crude parsley extract (not pure apiole) shows CYP1A inhibition
research_on_extract.implication: Don't need pure apiole - parsley seed oil or crushed seeds work

dangerous_traditional_use.mechanism: Stimulates uterine contractions, increases menstrual flow

historical_use_abortifacient.modern_status: No longer used medically - safer alternatives available

apiole_in_nutmeg.note: Nutmeg contains trace amounts of apiole in addition to myristicin and elemicin

crushed_parsley_seeds.method: Crush or grind fresh, steep in hot water or add to smoothie

optimal_use_for_oilahuasca.timing: Give with nutmeg (T-0) - both will inhibit CYP1A together

comparison_to_dmmda.assessment: 200mg apiole from 1ml oil = reasonable starting point

cyp450_inhibition.research_citation: Metabolism mediated interaction of α-asarone and Acorus calamus with Cytochrome P450 enzyme

clinical_significance.value: Adding calamus provides additional enzyme blockade

alpha_asarone.reason: Propenyl compounds cannot form reactive intermediates

asarone_isomers.oilahuasca_value: Primary value is as CYP450 inhibitor, not psychoactive substrate (unless γ-asarone present)

beta_asarone_safety_critical.research_verification: β-asarone was not detectable in the North American spontaneous diploid Acorus [Calamus var. Americanus]
beta_asarone_safety_critical.critical_rule: ONLY use North American diploid variety - must verify source or avoid entirely

beta_asarone_carcinogenicity.animal_studies: Long-term, high-dose feeding in rats caused liver tumors (hepatocarcinogenic)
beta_asarone_carcinogenicity.fda_action_1968: Calamus banned as food additive based on β-asarone content in Asian variety

extensive_history.duration: Used for centuries with no obvious cancer epidemic

why_historical_safety: North American natives used diploid (no β-asarone)
Asian use was often external or low-dose
Not used chronically in high amounts

psychoactive_reports.shulgin_note: There apparently is no report of central effects

only_use_if: Source verified as North American diploid

cyp3a4_inhibition.research_citation: Fennel was found having inhibitory effect on CYP 3A4
cyp3a4_inhibition.full_study: Inhibition on Human Liver Cytochrome P450 3A4 by Constituents of Fennel: Identification and Characterization of a Mechanism-Based Inactivator
cyp3a4_inhibition.key_finding: Fennel contains mechanism-based inactivators of CYP3A4!

type_of_inhibition.mechanism: Reactive metabolites form and covalently modify enzyme

responsible_compounds.not_anethole: Anethole is propenyl (doesn't form reactive intermediates same way)
responsible_compounds.status: More research needed to identify exact inactivating compounds

unknown_compounds_cyp3a4_inactivators.pathway: Fennel compounds → Metabolized by CYP3A4 → Reactive intermediates → CYP3A4 covalently modified → Enzyme dead

content.calculation: 10g fennel seeds × 0.3% estragole = 30mg estragole (modest, but contributes)

pleasant_flavor_advantage.use_as_carrier: Fennel tea base can mask bitter/unpleasant tastes of other herbs

fennel_seeds.method: Grind or crush, steep in hot water (tea) or add to smoothie

fennel_essential_oil.caution: High concentration - careful with dose (estragole concerns)

optimal_use.timing: 30-60 min before allylbenzenes (enzyme inhibition) or concurrent

safety.recommendation: Use fennel seeds (not concentrated oil), keep to reasonable amounts, don't use chronically

unique_contribution_sult_inhibition.research_finding: Sweet basil contains nevadensin, which is a SULT inhibitor

what_is_sult.function: Adds sulfate groups to compounds, makes them water-soluble for excretion

nevadensin.source: Found specifically in sweet basil (Ocimum basilicum)

sult_role_in_metabolism.normal_function: Lipophilic compound + PAPS → [SULT enzyme] → Sulfate conjugate → Water-soluble → EXCRETED in urine
sult_role_in_metabolism.with_sult_inhibition: Lipophilic compound + PAPS → [SULT BLOCKED] → Cannot sulfate → Remains lipophilic → ACCUMULATES

already_blocked.gst_function: No substrate even if enzyme present

phase_ii_blockade_strategy.result: Phase I metabolites cannot be conjugated by GSH (depleted) or sulfate (SULT blocked) → ACCUMULATE → Prolonged effects

methyleugenol_secondary.content: ~3-10% of basil essential oil (varies by variety)

triple_contribution.assessment: Elegant pharmacology - plant provides both 'drug' and 'potentiator' in one package!

fresh_sweet_basil.method: Eaten raw or added to smoothie
fresh_sweet_basil.note: Nevadensin content uncertain (may be higher in fresh)

basil_essential_oil.caution: Very high estragole concentration - use cautiously (estragole toxicity concerns)

option_a_with_inhibitors.rationale: Allows SULT inhibition to establish, ready when Phase I metabolites form

option_b_with_allylbenzenes.rationale: Estragole contributes to substrate loading, SULT inhibition develops over hours

timing.recommendation: Option A is probably better (pre-administration for enzyme inhibition)

nevadensin.toxicity: No known toxicity at culinary amounts

safety.recommendation: Use fresh or dried basil leaves (not concentrated oil) - safer than pure estragole, provides SULT inhibition benefit
